instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.WS_KBD_ONOFF_L: What is WS_KBD_ONOFF_L? WS_KBD_ONOFF_L is a signal that comes from the keyboard that tells the SMC that the power button has been pressed.  L means whatever before the L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. This signal directly affects SMC_ONOFF_L.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message:
Im working on a spillage board . There was spillage around the battery area and also around <CHIP>U4801</CHIP>.I changed this Ic. Now it turns on when adapter inserted and powers up. if you power it off it powers up again. If you remove the adapter it will stay on with the battery but will not charge. It will turn off using powerbutton but wont power on again.

F7140  = 11.8v
J0505 = pins 13/14 = 3.3v
<RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> = 10k

I have reballed and replaced the smc but still the same.
I have replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Any input appreciated

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message:
"F7140  = 11.8v"
I supposed this voltage is with battery connected.
Need to measure without battery.

Battery is not recognized at all by macOS?
Try known good battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message:
F7140 without battery is 12.54v

I have tried several batteries.
Board will not stay powered off with or without battery present if I short <SIGNAL>WS_KBD_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> unless I remove adapter power then short <SIGNAL>WS_KBD_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> it will stay off but not come back on with just battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message:
Test the board alone on the desk; no keyboard, nor RIO board connected.
Use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads and see if stays off.

What says macOS about battery?
I forgot the question mark on previous post...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message: Yeah I have just the board on the desk only fan attached. <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 still doesnt stay off. I havent boot into Mac to see. I was tryingot resolve this power issue first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> has steady 3V?
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops correctly when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

Check wake signals, to see if any keeps enabled when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>   has 3.4v steady
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>   drop to 0v when  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  is triggered

<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> stays high when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered
<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_SCI_L</SIGNAL> goes low
<SIGNAL>SMC_PME_S4_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> goes low
<SIGNAL>AP_PCIE_WAKE_L</SIGNAL>  goes low
<SIGNAL>AP_S0IX_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> goes low

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_SCI_L</SIGNAL> goes low
<SIGNAL>SMC_PME_S4_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> goes low"
And keep low?

When you turn it off (on battery alone), does it turn on by itself when you reconnect the charger (with battery present)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message:
They keep low as long as I keep <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low as soon as it goes high they then go high.
Yes it turns on with battery present by itself like if there was no battery present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a wont turn on with battery
threads.message: Ii changed <CHIP>U4850</CHIP> as it was a bit cruddy and it seems to be behaving itself now. Staying off when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered
